newsitem.title: USA: ASA discounts Greenpeace gene-altered soy claims.
newsitem.headline: ASA discounts Greenpeace gene-altered soy claims.

text.p: The president of the American Soybean Association discounted claims by environmental group Greenpeace that U.S. exporters could find enough non-genetically altered soybeans to meet Europe's import needs.

"I'm not sure that there are reliable sources of a quantity that would meet (the EU's) needs," David Erickson said in an interview. "Our initial research indicates that there is not a sufficient quantity."
Greenpeace said Wednesday that enough soybeans to meet European import requirements were grown in areas where the genetically altered seeds were not used.
"Through our research Greenpeace has identified that it is possible to supply the entire European market with RRS-free soybeans," the environmental group said in a statement.

"Production in soybean growing regions where Roundup Ready Soybean seeds were not commercially available and therefore RRS was not grown this year is approximately 12.25 to 13.6 million metric tonnes," it said.
Last year, the European Union imported 8.9 million tonnes of U.S. soybeans, according to USDA statistics.
Greenpeace has led protests to rouse consumer resistance against the soybeans in the United States and Europe.

The soybeans, called Roundup Ready because they are resistant to Monsanto Co's popular Roundup herbicide, account for about two percent of this year's projected 2.4 billion bushel (65 million tonne) U.S. soybean crop, according to ASA and industry estimates.
But several major U.S. soybean merchandisers, including Cargill Inc and Archer Daniels Midland Co, have said they will not separate or specially label the soybeans.

Greenpeace said in its statement that several U.S. exporters would supply Roundup-free soybeans. Calls to those exporters produced no sources who were willing to be named, but most said their companies served small, niche markets. Others said they did not currently ship soybeans but were planning to begin soon.
